Debut = {{nowrap|[[2005 Australian Grand Prix]]}} | Final = {{Latest F1GP}} | Races = {{F1cstat|RBR|entries}} ({{F1cstat|RBR|starts}} starts) | Engines = [[Cosworth]], [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]], [[Renault in Formula One|Renault]], [[TAG Heuer]], [[Honda in Formula One|Honda]], [[Red Bull Powertrains|RBPT]] | Cons_champ = 5 ({{F1|2010}}, {{F1|2011}}, {{F1|2012}}, {{F1|2013}}, {{F1|2022}}) | Drivers_champ = 6 ({{F1|2010}}, {{F1|2011}}, {{F1|2012}}, {{F1|2013}}, {{F1|2021}}, {{F1|2022}}) | Wins = {{F1cstat|RBR|wins}} | Podiums = {{F1cstat|RBR|podiums}} | Points = {{F1cstat|RBR|totalpoints}} | Poles = {{F1cstat|RBR|poles}} | Fastest_laps = {{F1cstat|RBR|fastestlaps}} | Last_season = 2022 | Last_position = 1st (759 pts) }} '''Red Bull Racing''', currently competing as '''Oracle Red Bull Racing''' and also known simply as '''Red Bull''' or '''RBR''', is a [[Formula One]] racing team, [[List of Formula One constructors#Team's nationality|racing under an Austrian licence]] and based in the United Kingdom. It is one of two Formula One teams owned by conglomerate [[Red Bull GmbH]], the other being [[Scuderia AlphaTauri]]. The Red Bull Racing team has been managed by [[Christian Horner]] since its formation in 2005.{{cite web|url=http://www.infiniti-redbullracing.com/cs/Satellite/en_INT/Red-Bull-Racing-Christian-Horner/001242969763138|title=Christian Horner: Team Principal|publisher=Infiniti Red Bull Racing|access-date=27 September 2013|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130714092438/http://www.infiniti-redbullracing.com/cs/Satellite/en_INT/Red-Bull-Racing-Christian-Horner/001242969763138|archive-date=14 July 2013}} Red Bull had [[Cosworth]] engines in 2005 and [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]] engines in 2006. The team used engines supplied by [[Renault in Formula One|Renault]] between 2007 and 2018 (from 2016 to 2018, the Renault engine was re-badged "[[TAG Heuer]]" following the breakdown in the relationship between Red Bull and Renault in {{F1|2015}}).{{Cite web|url=https://www.autosport.com/f1/news/140512/tag-heuer-stays-despite-red-bull-honda-deal|title=TAG Heuer extends Red Bull F1 deal despite 2019 Honda engine deal|first=Adam|last=Cooper|website=Autosport.com|access-date=5 June 2019|archive-date=5 June 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190605122508/https://www.autosport.com/f1/news/140512/tag-heuer-stays-despite-red-bull-honda-deal|url-status=live}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/formula1/14855045|work=[[BBC Sport]]|publisher=BBC|date=9 September 2011|access-date=9 September 2011|title=Red Bull extend Renault engine contract to 2016|archive-date=30 June 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180630153144/https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/formula1/14855045|url-status=live}} During this partnership, they won four successive Drivers' and Constructors' Championship titles from {{F1|2010}} to {{F1|2013}}, becoming the first Austrian team to win the title.{{cite web |url=http://www.fia.com/en-GB/mediacentre/pressreleases/ica/2009/Pages/ica_140409.aspx |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121117083045/http://www.fia.com/en-GB/mediacentre/pressreleases/ica/2009/Pages/ica_140409.aspx |archive-date=17 November 2012 |title= International Court of Appeal |publisher= [[FIA]] |access-date=17 November 2012}} The team began using Honda engines in {{F1|2019}}.{{cite web|url=https://www.motorauthority.com/news/1121512_2019-red-bull-racing-f1-car-revealed-fires-up-honda-engine-at-silverstone|title=2019 Red Bull Racing F1 car revealed, fires up Honda engine at Silverstone|publisher=Motorauthority|author=Sean Szymkowski|access-date=11 June 2019|archive-date=3 January 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220103135832/https://www.motorauthority.com/news/1121512_2019-red-bull-racing-f1-car-revealed-fires-up-honda-engine-at-silverstone|url-status=live}} The works Honda partnership culminated in 2021 following Red Bull driver [[Max Verstappen]]'s World Drivers' Championship victory, with Verstappen also winning the championship in [[2022 Formula One World Championship|2022]]. Honda left the sport officially after 2021, but is set to continue to supply complete engines from Japan to the team partly under [[Red Bull Powertrains]] branding until the end of 2025.{{cite web|url=https://www.formula1.com/en/latest/article.breaking-honda-and-red-bull-extend-power-unit-support-deal-until-2025.7hFIkY4W18FcmxNlWnB2ST.html|title=Honda and Red Bull extend power unit support deal until 2025|website=Formula 1|date=2 August 2022|access-date=8 April 2023|archive-date=11 February 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230211235156/https://www.formula1.com/en/latest/article.breaking-honda-and-red-bull-extend-power-unit-support-deal-until-2025.7hFIkY4W18FcmxNlWnB2ST.html|url-status=live}} == History == === Origins === {{See also|Stewart Grand Prix|Jaguar Racing}} The current Red Bull team can trace its origins back to the [[Stewart Grand Prix]] outfit that made its debut in {{F1|1997}}. [[Jackie Stewart]] sold his team to the [[Ford Motor Company]] late in 1999, and Ford made the decision to rebrand the team [[Jaguar Racing]] with little subsequent success over the next five years. [[File:Jean-Christophe Boullion 1995 Britain.jpg|thumb|left|Red Bull's involvement in Formula One dates back to {{F1|1995}}, when it first sponsored the [[Sauber]] team.]] The Jaguar Racing [[Formula One]] constructor and racing team was put up for sale in September 2004 when Ford decided it could "no longer make a compelling business case for any of its brands to compete in Formula One."{{cite news|title =Jaguar quits Formula One|url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/3665810.stm|work =BBC Sport|date =17 September 2004|access-date =28 January 2007|archive-date =3 February 2008|archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20080203141956/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/3665810.stm|url-status =live}} Red Bull, an [[energy drink]]s company, agreed its purchase of Jaguar Racing on the final day of the sale, 15 November 2004.{{cite news| title =Red Bull snaps up Jaguar F1 team| url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/formula_one/4012381.stm| work =BBC Sport| date =15 November 2004| access-date =28 January 2007| archive-date =17 January 2008| archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20080117133017/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/formula_one/4012381.stm| url-status =live}} [[BBC Sport]] reported that Ford asked bidders for a symbolic US$1 in return for a commitment to invest US$400 million in the team over three Grand Prix seasons. The team continued to have access to the [[Cosworth]] engine developed for their 2005 chassis, and the operation continued under the new title. [[Christian Horner]] was installed as the new team boss and lined up [[David Coulthard]] and [[Christian Klien]] to drive for the team. Red Bull Racing was not the start of Red Bull's involvement in Formula One, as they sponsored [[Sauber]] from 1995 to 2004. After buying a Formula One team of its own, Red Bull ended its long-term partnership with the Swiss team. Red Bull also runs a young drivers programme, [[Red Bull Junior Team]], whereby Red Bull sponsors promising young drivers. High-profile drivers who have received this backing include [[Enrique Bernoldi]], [[Christian Klien]], [[Patrick Friesacher]], [[Vitantonio Liuzzi]] and [[Scott Speed]]. Red Bull also sponsors many drivers and teams competing in the [[FIA Formula 2 Championship|Formula 2 Championship]], Formula One's "feeder" series. === Cosworth engines (2005) === ==== 2005 season ==== {{see also|2005 Formula One World Championship}} [[File:Vitantonio Liuzzi 2005 Britain.jpg|left|thumb|[[Vitantonio Liuzzi]] during free practice at the [[2005 British Grand Prix]]]] Red Bull's owner, [[Dietrich Mateschitz]], reportedly tried to recruit former Formula One driver and [[BMW Motorsport]] chief (and fellow Austrian) [[Gerhard Berger]] to help guide the team through its debut season. However, this was never realised. For {{F1|2005}}, the chassis was christened the [[Red Bull RB1|RB1]]. Red Bull Racing used [[Cosworth]] engines in its maiden year due to the ease of continuing with the engine Jaguar Racing used.{{Citation needed|date=May 2016}} Former [[McLaren]] driver David Coulthard led the team. Coulthard was chosen for his experience, considered ideal to help lead the fledgling team. For the second car, Red Bull shared the drive between two of its young sponsored drivers: [[Christian Klien]], who had driven for Jaguar in {{F1|2004}} and 2004 [[International Formula 3000|F3000]] champion [[Vitantonio Liuzzi]]. At first, it was announced that Klien and Liuzzi would swap driving duty every four races, but by the end of the season, Liuzzi had appeared only four times. Red Bull's first year in Formula One was a massive success compared to its predecessors, Jaguar Racing. They were 6th in the Constructors' Championship for most of the season, only beaten by the fast-improving [[BAR Honda]]s at the end of the season. In a single season, they amassed more points than Jaguar had in {{F1|2003}} and 2004. Coulthard, after a poor 2003 and 2004 with McLaren, was a revelation for the team while Klien showed that he had vastly improved from 2004.{{citation needed|reason=for Coulthard being a revelation|date=May 2016}} Overall they scored 34 points; 24 for Coulthard, 9 for Klien and 1 for Liuzzi. Red Bull was a consistent point and occasional [[Podium#Usage in motorsport|podium]] challenger for most of their debut season. American driver [[Scott Speed]], who rose through the ranks in the American equivalent of Red Bull Junior Team, [[Red Bull Driver Search]], was Red Bull Racing's [[third driver]] in 2005 for the [[2005 Canadian Grand Prix|Canadian]] and [[2005 United States Grand Prix|United States]] Grands Prix. Speed was attractive to Red Bull because of his American nationality which would raise the profile of both Red Bull and [[Formula One]] in America, a market where the sport has traditionally struggled to make an impact.{{Citation needed|date=May 2016}} === Ferrari engines (2006) === ==== 2006 season ==== {{see also|2006 Formula One World Championship}} On 23 April 2005, the team announced a deal to utilise customer [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]] engines in {{F1|2006}}. This coincided with a rule change mandating the use of [[V8 engine]]s, making it likely that both Red Bull Racing and Ferrari would use the same specification engine. Red Bull Racing continued to use [[Michelin]] tyres, rather than the [[Bridgestone]]s used by Ferrari. [[File:Formel1 Rennwagen 'RedBul-Racing' Hockenheim 2006 001.JPG|thumb|250x250px|Coulthard driving the [[Red Bull RB2|RB2]] at the [[2006 German Grand Prix]].]] On 8 November 2005, Red Bull Racing hired [[Adrian Newey]], the highly successful [[McLaren]] technical director.{{cite news|title =Newey makes shock Red Bull move|url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/formula_one/4416342.stm|work =BBC Sport|date =5 November 2005|access-date =28 January 2007|archive-date =4 December 2005|archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20051204042831/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/formula_one/4416342.stm|url-status =live}} On 15 December 2005, the team's second car, the [[Red Bull RB2]], hit the track for the first time. David Coulthard completed a handful of laps of the [[Silverstone Circuit|Silverstone]] circuit in England, and declared the new car was a "sexy looking thing".[https://web.archive.org/web/20080709004315/http://www.formula1.com/news/headlines/2005/12/3884.html Coulthard impressed with RB2] formula1.com, December 2005 In early testing Red Bull was plagued with cooling problems and overheating of car components.[http://www.f1technical.net/news/1541 Red Bull RB2 suffers overheating problems] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120217064658/http://www.f1technical.net/news/1541 |date=17 February 2012 }} f1testing.net, January 2006 At the opening race of the 2006 season in [[2006 Bahrain Grand Prix|Bahrain]], [[Christian Klien]] qualified eighth (ahead of [[Giancarlo Fisichella]]'s Renault and both BMWs). Coulthard had problems when he flat-spotted a tyre fighting with [[Nick Heidfeld]], and finished 10th; the cooling problems returned when his [[Ferrari]] engine expired on the slowing down lap, forcing a grid penalty for the following race. In [[2006 Malaysian Grand Prix|Malaysia]], Coulthard made up several places from the back of the grid but was forced to retire with hydraulic problems, while Klien had an opening lap incident with [[Kimi Räikkönen]] and after pitting for repairs also retired with hydraulic failure. Coulthard got a point in [[2006 Australian Grand Prix|Australia]] after Scott Speed was penalised for passing him under the yellow flags. The following races were marred with retirements and lowly finishes. Coulthard finished 3rd at [[2006 Monaco Grand Prix|Monaco]], the team's first podium finish. Team boss Christian Horner said before the race that if one of his cars were to finish on the podium, he would jump into a swimming pool at the track naked. He ended up jumping into the pool wearing only a red cape. Coincidentally both [[Stewart Grand Prix]] and [[Jaguar Racing]], the team's predecessors, also scored their maiden podiums at that race. [[File:Robert Doornbos 2006 Brazil.jpg|thumb|right|[[Robert Doornbos]] replaced Klien for the last three races of the {{F1|2006}} season.]] Coulthard scored a point at [[2006 Canadian Grand Prix|Montreal]], passing [[Jenson Button]] in the closing stages of the race despite starting in last place due to an engine change that warranted a grid penalty. Klien also fared well, driving the second RB2 to 11th position. At the {{F1 GP|2006|United States}} Klien retired along with eight other cars including [[Toro Rosso]] driver Scott Speed on the first lap after a series of first corner incidents. Coulthard finished 7th. The team finished 7th in the FIA Constructors' Championship, with 16 points, five points ahead of the struggling [[Williams F1|Williams]] team. Coulthard (14 pts) finished in 13th place in the drivers' standings, the departed Klien (2 pts) was classified in 18th position. Klien's replacement, [[Robert Doornbos]], failed to score any points. === Renault engines (2007–2015) === ====Customer era (2007–2010)==== =====2007 season===== {{see also|2007 Formula One World Championship}} [[File:Mark Webber 2007 Malaysia (cropped).jpg|thumb|250x250px|[[Mark Webber (racing driver)|Mark Webber]] driving for the team at the [[2007 Malaysian Grand Prix]].]] [[File:Mark Webber 2007 Britain 2.jpg|thumb|250px|right|[[Mark Webber (racing driver)|Mark Webber]] driving for RBR at the [[2007 British Grand Prix]]. Note the special ''Wings for Life'' livery.]] {{F1|2007}} saw the debut of the Adrian Newey designed [[Red Bull RB3|RB3]]. After lengthy discussions over Red Bull Racing's obligation to continue to use Ferrari engines for 2007, the team announced on 31 August 2006 they would use customer Renault engines for the 2007 season,{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/formula_one/6103248.stm |title=BBC SPORT | Motorsport | Formula One | Red Bull to be Renault powered |work=BBC News |date=31 October 2006 |access-date=28 April 2009 |archive-date=23 March 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220323052329/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/formula_one/6103248.stm |url-status=live }} the Ferrari contract being passed to [[Scuderia Toro Rosso]]. The team announced on 7 August 2006 that it had signed [[Mark Webber (racing driver)|Mark Webber]] to drive alongside Coulthard for the 2007 season, replacing [[Christian Klien]] who ended his association with the team. Klien was replaced by [[Robert Doornbos]] for the last three races of 2006. Doornbos became the team's non-racing third driver for 2007.{{cite news |url=http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/56487 |title=F1 News: Doornbos stays at Red Bull as test driver |publisher=autosport.com |date=26 January 2007 |access-date=28 April 2009 |archive-date=13 February 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080213225838/http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/56487 |url-status=live }} In 2007 Red Bull officially became an Austrian constructor by receiving an Austrian licence, though continued to operate from the same base in Britain.{{cite news |url=https://www.redbull.com/my-en/aston-martin-red-bull-racing-claim-60-grand-prix-wins |title=Aston Martin Red Bull Racing claim their 60th Formula One win |date=30 June 2019 |access-date=31 December 2019 |archive-date=3 May 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220503192432/https://www.redbull.com/my-en/aston-martin-red-bull-racing-claim-60-grand-prix-wins |url-status=live }} Despite qualifying in 7th place for his home race in [[2007 Australian Grand Prix|Melbourne]], [[Mark Webber (racing driver)|Mark Webber]] finished down in 13th due to a persistent problem with a fuel flap that closed as the pit mechanics went to put the fuel in and when it was opened it remained open until the next pit stop greatly increasing drag and decreasing airflow over the rear wing. It was worse for Coulthard however, who crashed heavily with [[Williams F1|Williams's]] [[Alexander Wurz]] in the late stages of the race. [[2007 Malaysian Grand Prix|Malaysia]] was more of the same for Webber, while Coulthard retired with brake problems. However, in [[2007 Bahrain Grand Prix|Bahrain]] the team showed improving pace, and Coulthard and Webber were running 7th (with Coulthard starting from the back) and 8th respectively before reliability problems put both out of the race in quick succession. However, in testing at [[Circuit de Catalunya|Barcelona]] Coulthard has set the fastest lap in the new configuration of the circuit (since superseded by [[Felipe Massa]]). Coulthard secured the team's first points by scoring a gritty 5th with a faulty gearbox on his closing laps in [[2007 Spanish Grand Prix|Spain]], while Webber was dogged with hydraulic problems all weekend, eventually retiring from the race after failing to set a competitive lap in qualifying. The performance hike the team experienced at the Catalan track left both drivers and team optimistic about their future results, with reliability troubles being as much a focus as the increase of their already competitive pace. Red Bull Racing further strengthened their technical department by hiring [[Geoff Willis]] as Technical Director on 17 July 2007.{{cite news| title =Geoff Willis joins Red Bull Technology| publisher =grandprix.com| url =http://www.grandprix.com/ns/ns19409.html| date =17 July 2007| access-date =18 July 2007| archive-date =13 July 2018| archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20180713074226/http://www.grandprix.com/ns/ns19409.html| url-status =live}} After this, the drivers seemed to have a stroke of good luck during the unpredictable and exciting [[2007 European Grand Prix]] in which Webber finished 3rd, his second career podium. Coulthard backed it up with a strong 5th which was made all the more impressive by the fact he started 20th on the grid after the team mistakenly kept him in the pits too long resulting in him not being able to complete another qualifying lap. Red Bull had a strong end to the season. Webber came close to victory at the [[2007 Japanese Grand Prix|Japanese Grand Prix]], but he was involved in a crash with [[Sebastian Vettel]]. During the same race, Coulthard again demonstrated his wet-weather ability and finished 4th. At the [[2007 Chinese Grand Prix|Chinese Grand Prix]], Red Bull had a competitive qualifying session. Coulthard achieved 5th on the grid, along with Webber in 9th. =====2008 season===== {{see also|2008 Formula One World Championship}} [[File:Redbull-webber2-spain-2008-lrg.jpg|thumb|[[Mark Webber (racing driver)|Mark Webber]] driving for RBR at the [[2008 Spanish Grand Prix]].]] Red Bull continued with the same drivers in {{F1|2008}} and had numbers 9 and 10 on their cars after finishing 5th in the 2007 Constructors' Championship. Red Bull presented the [[Red Bull RB4|RB4]] at the [[Circuito de Jerez|Jerez circuit]] on 16 January and announced that [[Sébastien Buemi]] would be their test and reserve driver for 2008 combining it with his GP2 drive with the [[Arden International]] GP2 team. After Webber retired from the [[2008 Australian Grand Prix|opening round]] he went on to score 5 consecutive points finishes. Coulthard had a tougher start to the 2008 campaign due to poor qualifying, but a 3rd place at [[2008 Canadian Grand Prix|Canada]] gave Red Bull their first podium since the [[2007 European Grand Prix]]. At the half-way mark, the team had notched up 24 points – the same as their total for the 2007 season – and were locked in a fierce battle with [[Toyota Racing (Formula One team)|Toyota]] and Renault for 4th in the Constructors' Championship. The team had also resolved the reliability problems that had dogged them the previous year. However, as the season progressed, Red Bull failed to keep up with their competitors. Red Bull scored just 5 points in the last 10 races, and [[Scuderia Toro Rosso|Toro Rosso]] – the Red Bull 'B team' – had overhauled their total by the season's end and won the rain-affected {{F1 GP|2008|Italian}}, becoming the first Red Bull-owned team to win a race. This fact led many to claim that the Renault engine powering the Red Bull was lacking in horsepower compared to the Ferrari and Mercedes engines. For the 2009 season, Renault was allowed to equalise the difference in engine power compared to their competitors after the single-year freeze in engine development from 2007.{{cite news |last=Elizalde |first=Pablo |date=12 December 2008 |title=Renault get engine boost for 2009 |work=[[Autosport]] |publisher=[[Haymarket Media Group|Haymarket Publications]] |url=http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/72457 |access-date=20 November 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210411011629/https://www.autosport.com/f1/news/renault-gets-engine-boost-for-2009-4426771/4426771/ |archive-date=25 November 2022}} Webber notched up his 50th top ten grid position in 107 Grands Prix at the {{F1 GP|2008|Spanish}}. Coulthard announced his retirement from Formula One at the {{F1 GP|2008|British}} and, despite hopes for a strong final home Grand Prix, was forced to retire on the first lap, which also occurred at his final race in [[2008 Brazilian Grand Prix|Brazil]] where he retired at the second corner. =====2009 season===== {{see also|2009 Formula One World Championship}} For {{F1|2009}}, Red Bull Racing launched their new [[Red Bull RB5|RB5]] chassis virtually on 8 February utilising a 3D computer-generated video narrated by Sebastian Vettel. The physical launch of the car was held the next day. The team secured their first pole position at the {{F1 GP|2009|Chinese}} with Sebastian Vettel, posting the fastest time with just a single qualifying lap in Q3. Mark Webber qualified in third on the grid. The next day, Vettel won, with Webber second.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/motorsport/formula_one/8006717.stm|title=Vettel seals first Red Bull win|date=19 April 2009|work=BBC Sport|access-date=20 April 2009|first=Chris|last=Whyatt|archive-date=20 April 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090420012117/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/motorsport/formula_one/8006717.stm|url-status=live}} Vettel's victory, in rain-soaked conditions, marked Red Bull Racing's first-ever win{{cite news |title=Red Bull Racing Launch 2009 F1 Car Virtually |work=PopSci.com.au |date=9 February 2009 |url=http://popsci.com.au/cars/article/2009-02/red-bull-racing-launch-2009-f1-car-virtually |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090210111912/http://popsci.com.au/cars/article/2009-02/red-bull-racing-launch-2009-f1-car-virtually |archive-date=10 February 2009 |access-date =9 February 2009}} (although the team's predecessor, [[Stewart Grand Prix|Stewart GP]], had won the [[1999 European Grand Prix]] courtesy of [[Johnny Herbert]]).Jackie Stewart Winning Is Not Enough, pg. 394–5, {{ISBN|978 0 7553 1539 0}} [[File:Sebastian Vettel Jerez Feb 2009 3593a.jpg|thumb|[[Sebastian Vettel]] driving the [[Red Bull RB5|RB5]] at pre-season testing at Jerez.]] In the next race at [[2009 Bahrain Grand Prix|Bahrain]] after qualifying 3rd,{{cite web|url=http://www.formula1.com/results/season/2009/807/6620|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090428130722/http://www.formula1.com/results/season/2009/807/6620|archive-date=28 April 2009 |title=2009 Formula 1 Gulf Air Bahrain Grand Prix – Qualifying Results |publisher=Formula1.com |access-date=28 April 2009}} Vettel finished second behind [[Jenson Button]] and collected another eight world championship points.{{cite web|url=http://www.formula1.com/results/season/2009/807/6621/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090428132009/http://www.formula1.com/results/season/2009/807/6621/|archive-date=28 April 2009 |title=2009 Formula 1 Gulf Air Bahrain Grand Prix – Race Results |publisher=Formula1.com |access-date=28 April 2009}} At the {{F1 GP|2009|Spanish}}, Webber and Vettel finished third and fourth respectively, after having qualified fifth and second. In [[2009 Turkish Grand Prix|Turkey]], Webber and Vettel finished second and third respectively. At the {{F1 GP|2009|British}} the car had new upgrades and Sebastian Vettel won after qualifying on pole position, ending championship leader Jenson Button's run of four straight wins. The team scored another 1–2 at the {{F1 GP|2009|German}} with Mark Webber (who scored his first win despite being given a drive-through penalty earlier on) leading home Sebastian Vettel. Mark Webber also took his second Formula One victory at the {{F1 GP|2009|Brazilian}}. Another 1–2 finish for the team was achieved at the season-ending {{F1 GP|2009|Abu Dhabi}}, this time with Vettel finishing ahead of Webber. Vettel finished second in the Drivers' Championship with 84 points, 11 behind Jenson Button. Mark Webber finished fourth with 69.5 points. The team also finished second in the Constructors' Championship with 153.5 points, 18.5 points behind [[Brawn GP]]. =====2010 season===== {{see also|2010 Formula One World Championship}} For the 2010 season, the team retained both [[Mark Webber (racing driver)|Mark Webber]] and [[Sebastian Vettel]], with Renault remaining the engine supplier. At the opening round, the {{F1 GP|2010|Bahrain}}, Vettel took pole position while Webber qualified sixth. Vettel led the race until he slowed due to a spark-plug failure,{{Cite web|title=Spark plug was to blame for Vettel's power loss|url=http://en.espnf1.com/bahrain/motorsport/story/11380.html|access-date=17 August 2020|website=ESPN UK|language=en|archive-date=14 April 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100414040805/http://en.espnf1.com/bahrain/motorsport/story/11380.html|url-status=live}} while the two [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]]s and [[Lewis Hamilton]] overtook Vettel. Vettel finished fourth, and Webber finished eighth. In [[2010 Australian Grand Prix|Australia]], Vettel again took pole, with Webber in the second position. Vettel led the race and again looked set to take the race, but he reported a vibration of one of the front wheels on his car. The problem seemed to subside, and the decision was made to keep him on the track rather than pit him. A few corners later, the problem struck again, and Vettel ran off the track and subsequently retired, due to brake failure. Webber got wheelspin off the line and gave up one position on the run to the first right-handed corner. Subsequent errors led to him dropping a few more places, and near the end of the race, he crashed with Hamilton, destroying his front wing. He pitted to get a new one, and finished ninth, scoring two points. In [[2010 Malaysian Grand Prix|Malaysia]], Webber took pole with Vettel in the third position. Vettel managed to pass both [[Nico Rosberg]] and Webber before the first corner, leading for all bar two laps en route to his and the team's first victory of the year. Webber led the other two laps and eventually finished second, with the team moving up into third in the Constructors' Championship. [[File:Vettel abu dabi 2010.jpg|thumb|left|Vettel won the 2010 World Drivers' Championship at the season-ending [[2010 Abu Dhabi Grand Prix|Abu Dhabi Grand Prix]].]] The team once again scored pole position in [[2010 Chinese Grand Prix|China]], when Vettel managed to set a faster time than Webber, who completed the front row. Webber overtook Vettel at the start, but both were overtaken by [[Fernando Alonso]], who was later given a penalty for a false start. The race was then hit by rain and [[Jenson Button]] made the best strategy call and won the race, Vettel finished sixth whilst Webber was eighth. This left Vettel and Webber fifth and seventh in the Drivers' Championship respectively, and the team in third in the Constructors' Championship. At the {{F1 GP|2010|Spanish}} the two drivers were the other way around, with Webber on pole position and Vettel second on the grid. Webber won the race without too much trouble.{{citation needed|reason=without too much trouble|date=May 2016}} Vettel, however, suffered brake problems and dropped to fourth – this became third when Hamilton had a puncture and crashed from second on the penultimate lap. Webber took pole position again at the {{F1 GP|2010|Monaco}}; Vettel qualified third behind [[Renault in Formula One|Renault]]'s [[Robert Kubica]], but overtook him at the start. Webber won the race and Vettel finished in second place.{{cite web|url=http://www.formula1.com/news/headlines/2010/5/10796.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100518181018/http://www.formula1.com/news/headlines/2010/5/10796.html|archive-date=18 May 2010 |title=Race – Webber and Red Bull hit Monaco jackpot |publisher=Formula1.com |date=16 May 2010 |access-date=26 June 2010}} After the race, Webber was leading the championship after being in seventh after China, with Vettel in second place (this was only by countback though because both drivers were on 78 points). The team was leading the Constructors' Championship. At the {{F1 GP|2010|Turkish}}, Webber again took pole position, taking the team's run of pole positions to seven consecutive races, with Vettel third on the grid. Following the pit stops, Webber and Vettel were running first and second until lap 40, when Vettel attempted to overtake Webber, leading to a collision between the two. Webber finished third, while Vettel was forced to retire. Neither driver took 100% of responsibility while senior members of the team alluded to the thought that Webber had not provided "enough room" for Vettel.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/motorsport/formula_one/8713780.stm|title=Mark Webber & Sebastian Vettel play crash blame game|work=[[BBC Sport]]|publisher=BBC|date=30 May 2010|access-date=11 December 2012|archive-date=4 June 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100604030142/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/motorsport/formula_one/8713780.stm|url-status=live}} In [[2010 Canadian Grand Prix|Canada]], Hamilton took pole position – the first non-Red Bull pole of the year. Webber and Vettel were second and third respectively in qualifying before the pair finished fourth and fifth in the race. The team admitted that it was a track that the car struggled with. At the {{F1 GP|2010|European}} in [[Valencia, Spain]], Vettel won from pole position, leading every lap of the race. Webber collided with the Lotus of [[Heikki Kovalainen]], flipping his Red Bull car into a somersault before landing and crashing into a tyre barrier. At the {{F1 GP|2010|British}} at [[Silverstone Circuit|Silverstone]], Vettel took pole position but after a bad start, he got a puncture and subsequently dropped to the back of the field, eventually finishing seventh. Webber, who started from second, won after leading for the entire race. Vettel qualified in pole position in front of the two Ferraris in [[2010 German Grand Prix|Germany]], but finished his home race behind the pair in third place. Webber qualified in fourth but finished in sixth behind both the McLaren cars. During the race [[Felipe Massa]] controversially let [[Fernando Alonso]] past into the lead to win the race after a message from the team. Red Bull team principal Christian Horner said: "That was the most blatant team order ever".{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/formula_one/8852910.stm|work=[[BBC Sport]]|publisher=BBC|title=Red Bull boss Horner criticises Ferrari "team orders"|date=25 July 2010|access-date=31 July 2010| archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20100727134038/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/formula_one/8852910.stm| archive-date= 27 July 2010 | url-status= live}} He also criticised Ferrari for not letting their drivers race each other. At the {{F1 GP|2010|Hungarian}} in [[Budapest]], Vettel again took pole position and was leading until the safety car came out. He was second behind Webber, who started second and was then given a drive-through penalty for exceeding the ten-car maximum distance between himself and the safety car. This cost him second place and he finished third. Webber won the race after using his super-soft tyres for over half the race to build up a lead to keep him ahead after his stop. Webber won with [[Fernando Alonso]] ten seconds behind in second place. The {{F1 GP|2010|Belgian}} saw Webber claim pole position, despite McLaren and Ferrari having a straight-line speed advantage. At the start, the anti-stall device on Webber's car came on, dropping the Australian to 5th. Vettel, meanwhile in 3rd (after starting 4th) was chasing Jenson Button for 2nd place when he collided with the Brit at the Bus Stop. After sensing an inside passing opportunity, Vettel attempted to quickly change direction while under braking, causing the car to spear into the side of Button's McLaren. Button retired from the race, while Vettel was able to pit for repairs. He subsequently received a drive-through penalty for his action and suffered a rear tyre puncture while attempting to overtake [[Vitantonio Liuzzi]], finishing 15th. Webber was able to capitalise on the DNF of Button and Alonso, as well as a mistake by Renault's [[Robert Kubica]], during his pit stop, and finish 2nd, behind race winner Hamilton. At the {{F1 GP|2010|Italian}} in [[Monza]], Webber had a bad start and was 9th from 4th place on the grid after the first lap. Vettel had brake binding problems for a short period, around lap 20, and he too dropped back a place but was then back on the pace. Webber was held back by [[Nico Hülkenberg]] in the latter part of the race, until he passed, and finished 6th. Vettel stayed out on soft tyres until the penultimate lap, doing better lap times than Webber and overtaking Mark when he pitted, to finish fourth. At the {{F1 GP|2010|Korean}} in [[Yeongam]], Vettel gave the team its 19th pole position, while Webber started second, making it a Red Bull front row. On lap 18, Webber spun and hit the wall, and hit the [[Mercedes-Benz in Formula One|Mercedes]] of [[Nico Rosberg]], causing both drivers to retire. Worse was to come for the team when Vettel's engine failed just 10 laps from the finish, while he was in the lead, and the German retired and handed his lead to [[Fernando Alonso]] in the [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]]. Red Bull had suffered their first double retirement since the [[2008 Australian Grand Prix]] and as a result, Webber lost his championship lead and Vettel's engine failure prevented him from leading the championship for the first time in 2010, but the team still led the Constructors' Championship. At the {{F1 GP|2010|Brazilian}} in [[São Paulo]], Red Bull Racing became Constructors' Champion for the first time after Sebastian Vettel and Mark Webber finished 1–2 in the race, enough to finish ahead of [[McLaren]] and [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]]. In doing so Red Bull became the first Austrian team to win the Formula One Constructors' Championship. Christian Horner stated that the main goal had been achieved and that now his remaining aim was to win the Drivers' Championship and put the icing on the cake of Red Bull's year. In some other teams, the drivers would have been told to change positions, to improve better placed Mark Webber's chances to win the drivers' title in the last race, but the team insisted that the faster driver should win the race, and kept being reluctant to give any orders of the kind "let your teammate pass" to their drivers. In the [[2010 Abu Dhabi Grand Prix|final race]] at [[Abu Dhabi]], Sebastian Vettel won the race and the Formula One Drivers' Championship. Red Bull finished the year with a total of 9 Grand Prix victories with five going to Sebastian Vettel and four going to Mark Webber. Red Bull claimed a total of 15 pole positions with 10 going to Vettel and five going to Webber. The team scored six fastest laps three scored by Vettel and three scored by Webber. Horner also praised the sportsmanship of both drivers stating that they conducted themselves in a well orderly and mannered fashion.{{cite news|url=http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/88286|title=Horner praises drivers' sportsmanship|work=autosport.com|publisher=[[Haymarket Group|Haymarket Publications]]|date=14 November 2010|access-date=14 November 2010|first=Steven|last=English|archive-date=16 November 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101116132623/http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/88286|url-status=live}} ====Renault full-works partnership era (2011–2015)==== =====2011 season===== {{see also|2011 Formula One World Championship}} [[File:2011 Italian GP - Vettel.jpg|thumb|right|240px|[[Sebastian Vettel]] competing at the [[2011 Italian Grand Prix]].]] Red Bull Racing was officially promoted to [[Renault F1|Renault]]'s full-works partnership status, receiving free engines as Renault's full-works constructor team was rebranded to [[Lotus Renault GP]].{{cite web|title=Red Bull get budget boost through Infiniti link-up|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/motorsport/formula_one/9409120.stm|work=bbc.co.uk|publisher=BBC Sport|date=1 March 2011|accessdate=1 March 2011|archive-date=6 January 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220106040912/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/motorsport/formula_one/9409120.stm|url-status=live}}{{cite web|title=Red Bull now Renault's works team – Horner|url=http://www.motorsport.com/f1/news/f1-red-bull-now-renault-s-works-team-horner/411557/|work=motorsport.com|publisher=[[motorsport.com]]|date=15 September 2011|accessdate=15 September 2011|archive-date=16 February 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230216153547/https://www.motorsport.com/f1/news/f1-red-bull-now-renault-s-works-team-horner/411557/|url-status=live}} Both [[Sebastian Vettel]] and [[Mark Webber (racing driver)|Mark Webber]] were retained by the team for the {{F1|2011}} season, as was engine supplier Renault.{{cite news | url = news|title=Webber signs with Red Bull for 2011|url=http://www.f1fanatic.co.uk/2010/06/07/webber-signs-with-red-bull-for-2011/|first=Keith|last=Collantine|work=F1 Fanatic|publisher=Keith Collantine|date=7 June 2010|access-date=7 June 2010|archive-date=10 June 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100610221800/http://www.f1fanatic.co.uk/2010/06/07/webber-signs-with-red-bull-for-2011/|url-status=live}}{{cite web|title=Red Bull Racing and Renault Announce New Agreement|url=http://www.renaultsportf1.com/RED-BULL-RACING-AND-RENAULT.html?lang=fr|work=[[Renault Sport F1]]|access-date=2 January 2012|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924090214/http://www.renaultsportf1.com/RED-BULL-RACING-AND-RENAULT.html?lang=fr|archive-date=24 September 2015}} Vettel defended his world title – becoming the ninth driver to do so – after winning eleven of the season's races, and also achieved 15 pole positions during the season, breaking [[Nigel Mansell]]'s record from the {{F1|1992}} season. Webber finished the season in third place in the championship, taking one victory, in the final race of the season in [[2011 Brazilian Grand Prix|Brazil]]. The team also defended their respective title, as they finished the season with 650 points in the Constructors' Championship, 153 points ahead of the next closest team, [[McLaren]]. [[Nissan]]'s premium automotive brand [[Infiniti]] joined Red Bull Racing as an official partner for the 2011 and 2012 seasons which saw Infiniti logos appear on the race car, [[racing suit|drivers overalls]] and team kit. =====2012 season===== {{see also|2012 Formula One World Championship}} For the 2012 season, Red Bull retained the duo of [[Sebastian Vettel]] and [[Mark Webber (racing driver)|Mark Webber]] from the previous three years. Webber was signed on a one-year contract extension while Vettel continued under his current multi-year agreement, ending at the end of 2014. Vettel won the Drivers' Championship for a third consecutive time in 2012 making him the youngest triple World Champion, surpassing [[Ayrton Senna]].{{cite news|url=http://www.formula1.com/news/headlines/2011/8/12448.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111010074856/http://www.formula1.com/news/headlines/2011/8/12448.html|archive-date=10 October 2011|title=Webber re-signs with Red Bull for 2012|work=Formula1.com|publisher=[[Formula One Group|Formula One Administration]]|date=27 August 2010|access-date=6 December 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://www.formula1.com/news/headlines/2011/3/11814.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110316175233/http://www.formula1.com/news/headlines/2011/3/11814.html|archive-date=16 March 2011|title=Vettel to stay at Red Bull until 2014|work=Formula1.com|publisher=[[Formula One Group|Formula One Administration]]|date=14 March 2011|access-date=6 December 2012}} =====2013 season===== {{see also|2013 Formula One World Championship}} [[File:Sebastian Vettel overtaking Mark Webber 2013 Malaysia 1.jpg|thumb|left|270px|[[Sebastian Vettel]] disobeyed team orders and made a controversial overtake on teammate [[Mark Webber (racing driver)|Mark Webber]] at the [[2013 Malaysian Grand Prix]].]] The team was renamed Infiniti Red Bull Racing for the 2013 season following the announcement that premium automotive brand Infiniti had become Title Partner and Vehicle Performance Partner of the team.{{cite news|url=http://www.formula1.com/news/headlines/2012/11/14121.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121128042218/http://www.formula1.com/news/headlines/2012/11/14121.html|archive-date=28 November 2012|title=Infiniti to become Red Bull Racing title sponsor|work=Formula1.com|publisher=[[Formula One Group|Formula One Administration]]|date=25 November 2012|access-date=25 November 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://cms.infiniti-redbullracing.com/sites/default/files/press_release_group/press_release/infiniti_to_become_title_partner_of_red_bull_racing_from_2013.25-11-2012.pdf|title=Infiniti to become title partner of Red Bull Racing from 2013|work=Red Bull Racing|publisher=[[Red Bull]]|date=25 November 2012|access-date=25 November 2012|archive-date=4 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304042918/http://cms.infiniti-redbullracing.com/sites/default/files/press_release_group/press_release/infiniti_to_become_title_partner_of_red_bull_racing_from_2013.25-11-2012.pdf|url-status=dead}} Infiniti Red Bull continued with drivers [[Sebastian Vettel]] and [[Mark Webber (racing driver)|Mark Webber]] for the fifth consecutive season. As with 2012, Webber was signed on a single year contract while Vettel continued to honour his current multi-year agreement.{{cite news|url=http://www.formula1.com/news/headlines/2012/7/13569.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120712120721/http://www.formula1.com/news/headlines/2012/7/13569.html|archive-date=12 July 2012|title=Webber to stay at Red Bull for 2013|work=Formula1.com|publisher=[[Formula One Group|Formula One Administration]]|date=10 July 2012|access-date=6 December 2012}} In [[2013 Australian Grand Prix|Australia]], the first race of the season, Vettel placed the new RB9 on pole position but struggled in the race finishing in 3rd place behind title rivals of 2012, Kimi Räikkönen and Fernando Alonso whilst teammate Webber finished in sixth place. In [[2013 Malaysian Grand Prix|Malaysia]] the team went better with Vettel again putting the RB9 on pole, but unlike in Australia winning the race, albeit under heavy controversy. Vettel won the race after disobeying team orders, and so despite the 1–2 result, the race was overshadowed by Vettel's actions. In [[2013 Chinese Grand Prix|China]], the third race of the season, Vettel qualified in 9th whilst Webber qualified 14th after an issue with his fuel pick up led him to have to stop the car on the track. Infiniti Red Bull failed to give the FIA a 1-litre fuel sample, therefore, placing Webber at the back of the grid. The downfall of his performance was matched when a collision and then a dislodged wheel nut led to Webber not completing the race. Vettel finished in 4th, retaining his lead in the World Championship. In [[2013 Bahrain Grand Prix|Bahrain]], the fourth race of the season, Vettel qualified in second place behind Nico Rosberg. Webber qualified fifth but after a 3 place grid penalty started the race in seventh. In the race, Webber failed to improve on his qualifying position finishing 7th whilst his teammate won the race in a dominating fashion. After the fourth race of the season, Infiniti Red Bull finished the first round of flyaway races leading both the Drivers' and Constructors' Championships. [[Sebastian Vettel]] extended his contract with Infiniti Red Bull Racing until the end of 2015, despite interests in racing for Ferrari and Mercedes. At the {{F1 GP|2013|British}}, Mark Webber announced his retirement from Formula One at the end of the season, having signed a deal with Porsche in the [[FIA World Endurance Championship]] for 2014.{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-06-27/formula-one3a-mark-webber-to-retire-at-end-of-season/4786120 |title=Formula One: Mark Webber to retire at end of season |date=27 June 2013 |newspaper=ABC News |publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] |access-date=27 June 2013 |archive-date=27 April 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190427142017/https://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-06-27/formula-one3a-mark-webber-to-retire-at-end-of-season/4786120 |url-status=live }} It was then announced before the Italian Grand Prix that [[Daniel Ricciardo]], the Toro Rosso driver, would replace Webber for the 2014 season, ending talk of Lotus's Kimi Räikkönen taking Webber's seat. At the {{F1 GP|2013|Italian}}, Vettel secured the team's 50th pole position, and 40th Grand Prix victory.{{cite web |date=7 September 2013 |title=Front-row lockout in Monza as Seb claims team's 50th pole |url=http://www.redbull.com/cs/Satellite/en_INT/Article/Front-row-lockout-in-Monza-as-Seb-claims-team%E2%80%99s-021243357979022 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141217173534/https://www.redbull.com/cs/Satellite/en_INT/Article/Front-row-lockout-in-Monza-as-Seb-claims-team%E2%80%99s-021243357979022 |archive-date=25 November 2022 |access-date=18 November 2014 |work=Red Bull Racing |publisher=Red Bull Racing Limited}}{{cite web |date=8 September 2013 |title=MONZA MAGIC AS SEB TAKES TEAM'S 40TH WIN |url=http://www.redbullracing.com/article/monza-magic-seb-takes-teams-40th-win |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170304140001/https://www.redbullracing.com/article/monza-magic-seb-takes-teams-40th-win |archive-date=25 November 2022 |access-date=18 November 2014 |work=Red Bull Racing |publisher=Red Bull Racing Limited}} At the {{F1 GP|2013|Indian}}, Vettel sealed the Drivers' Championship title, and in doing so, won the Constructors' Championship for Infiniti Red Bull Racing for the fourth consecutive year.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/formula1/24691160 |title=Sebastian Vettel wins fourth F1 world title at the Indian GP |date=27 October 2013 |website=[[BBC Sport]] |publisher=BBC |access-date=29 October 2013 |archive-date=5 January 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160105090504/http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/formula1/24691160 |url-status=live }} =====2014 season===== {{see also|2014 Formula One World Championship}} [[File:Daniel Ricciardo 2014 Singapore FP1.jpg|thumb|[[Daniel Ricciardo]] won three races in 2014 with the [[Red Bull RB10]].]] Infiniti Red Bull started the season with reigning World Champion [[Sebastian Vettel]] and [[Daniel Ricciardo]] who replaced [[Mark Webber (racing driver)|Mark Webber]] after he had announced in 2013 that he would be moving to [[Porsche]] in the [[FIA World Endurance Championship|World Endurance Championship]] for 2014.{{cite news|title=Formula One: Mark Webber to retire at end of season|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-06-27/formula-one3a-mark-webber-to-retire-at-end-of-season/4786120|access-date=6 December 2013|archive-date=27 April 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190427142017/https://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-06-27/formula-one3a-mark-webber-to-retire-at-end-of-season/4786120|url-status=live}}{{cite news|title=Red Bull to confirm Daniel Ricciardo as Mark Webber's replacement for 2014 season|url=http://www1.skysports.com/f1/news/24239/8878111/|access-date=6 December 2013|newspaper=SkySports F1|archive-date=10 December 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131210171834/http://www1.skysports.com/f1/news/24239/8878111/|url-status=live}} In pre-season testing, it became clear, not just from Red Bull, but other Renault teams that the Renault engine was very unreliable and down on power compared to the Ferrari and Mercedes engines. Renault struggled to get the new hybrid engine to function properly all through testing with the combustion engine, the kinetic recovery system, and the turbo all unable to work as one. At the {{F1 GP|2014|Australian}}, Ricciardo had qualified second on his first race for the team while Vettel qualified a rather distant 13th being at least 1.8 seconds off pole-sitter Lewis Hamilton. In the race itself, Ricciardo finished second while Vettel retired after just three laps due to a power unit failure. However, after the race, Ricciardo was disqualified for violating the FIA's new rule of capping fuel use at 100 kg per hour in each race. He thus lost his podium finish. Red Bull appealed this decision on 14 April but lost their case. At the {{F1 GP|2014|Malaysian}} Vettel qualified second while Ricciardo qualified fifth. On lap 49 Ricciardo had to retire due to a technical failure while Vettel went on to finish third and earn his first podium finish of the season. Ricciardo was hit with a ten-place grid penalty for the {{F1 GP|2014|Bahrain}}, due to an unsafe release by Red Bull at one of his pit stops. At the {{F1 GP|2014|Bahrain}} Ricciardo qualified third, but dropped to 13th due to his ten-place grid penalty from the previous week. Vettel qualified 11th. Ricciardo managed to finish fourth, obtaining his first championship points of the season. Vettel finished sixth. At the {{F1 GP|2014|Chinese}}, under harsh weather conditions, Ricciardo qualified 2nd, with Vettel qualifying third. Ricciardo finished in 4th again, nearly 25 seconds ahead of his teammate Vettel, who finished 5th. Ricciardo would go on to obtain the first podium finish in his career as a Formula One driver at the {{F1 GP|2014|Spanish}}, after qualifying third, over a second behind polesitter Lewis Hamilton. Vettel did not participate in Q3 due to problems with his gearbox, which ultimately needed to be replaced, incurring a five-place grid penalty. Despite starting from the 15th position, Vettel managed to finish the race in 4th, setting the fastest lap of the race in the process. In [[2014 Canadian Grand Prix|Canada]], Ricciardo won the race, achieving his first career victory in Formula One. After an {{F1 GP|2014|Austrian}} with poor results, including Vettel's retirement, Christian Horner described the performance of the Renault engine as "unacceptable."{{cite web |url=http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/114598 |title=Red Bull: Renault form is unacceptable |work=Autosport.com |publisher=[[Haymarket Media Group|Haymarket Publications]] |author=Noble, Jonathan |date=22 June 2014 |access-date=24 June 2014 |archive-date=25 June 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140625081905/http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/114598 |url-status=live }} He also mocked Renault in an interview with [[Servus TV]] by saying that "the big difference between Mercedes and Renault is that when a driver with a Mercedes engine pushes the overtake button his car goes faster. When our drivers, which have a Renault engine, push the button, the car stops!"{{cite web |url=http://www.f1i.com/infos/horner-egratigne-encore-v6-turbo-renault/ |title=Horner égratigne encore le V6 turbo Renault |trans-title=Horner attacks more the Renault V6 turbo |language=fr |publisher=Fi.com |last=Demoen |first=Grégory |date=24 June 2014 |access-date=25 June 2014 |quote=La grande différence entre le Mercedes et le Renault, c'est que lorsqu'un pilote équipé d'un bloc Mercedes appuie sur le bouton pour doubler, sa voiture va plus vite. Quand nos pilotes, qui ont un moteur Renault, poussent sur le bouton, la voiture s'arrête ! |archive-date=25 June 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140625123519/http://www.f1i.com/infos/horner-egratigne-encore-v6-turbo-renault/ |url-status=live }} =====2015 season===== {{see also|2015 Formula One World Championship}} {{expand section|date=March 2016}} [[File:Red Bull duo 2015 Malaysia Race 2.jpg|thumb|[[Daniil Kvyat]] and [[Daniel Ricciardo]] at the [[2015 Malaysian Grand Prix]]]] Daniel Ricciardo returned for a second season with the team. At the previous year's {{F1 GP|2014|Japanese}}, the team announced that Vettel would leave after the 2014 season. He was replaced by [[Daniil Kvyat]] for 2015, who had spent a single season with the junior [[Scuderia Toro Rosso#2014|Toro Rosso]] team.{{cite news|url=http://motorsports.nbcsports.com/2014/10/03/sebastian-vettel-leaving-red-bull-at-end-of-season-daniil-kvyat-to-replace-him/|title=Sebastian Vettel leaving Red Bull at end of season, Ferrari-bound; Daniil Kvyat to replace him|work=MotorSportsTalk|publisher=[[NBC Sports]]|date=3 October 2014|access-date=15 December 2014|first1=Chris|last1=Estrada|first2=Luke|last2=Smith|archive-date=10 September 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150910025916/http://motorsports.nbcsports.com/2014/10/03/sebastian-vettel-leaving-red-bull-at-end-of-season-daniil-kvyat-to-replace-him/|url-status=live}} 2015 for Infiniti Red Bull was seen initially as a continuous resurgence for the team. It was expected from the progress Renault made with the engine in 2014 that in 2015 it would be close to the Mercedes duo of Hamilton and Rosberg. However, it quickly became apparent that reliability, power, and drivability were all major issues that plagued the team through the season. At the {{F1 GP|2015|Australian}} Ricciardo qualified 7th while Kvyat qualified 13th. Kvyat failed to start the race due to a gearbox failure, whilst Ricciardo finished the race in sixth, a lap down from the race winner, Lewis Hamilton. The team scored their best finish in [[2015 Hungarian Grand Prix|Hungary]], where Ricciardo and Kvyat finished 2–3. Their only opportunity to win a race occurred at the {{F1 GP|2015|United States}}, however, both of the team's drivers made some mistakes allowing both of the Mercedes cars to pass them. Lewis Hamilton won the race and, as a result, his third Formula One World Championship. Come the end of the season, it was the first winless season for Infiniti Red Bull since 2008, and come seasons end, Red Bull wanted to end its partnership with Renault due to the lack of progress and confidence expressed by Renault. Red Bull would however be unable to agree to have another engine instead opting to run Renault engines for the 2016 season but rebadged as TAG-Heuer. They ended the season in fourth place on 187 points with Kvyat in seventh (95 points) and Ricciardo in eighth (92 points), their lowest finish position in seven years.{{Cite web|url=https://www.statsf1.com/en/2015.aspx|title=2015|website=www.statsf1.com|access-date=22 January 2019|archive-date=3 April 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190403133943/https://www.statsf1.com/en/2015.aspx|url-status=live}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.statsf1.com/en/red-bull.aspx|title=Red Bull • STATS F1|website=www.statsf1.com|access-date=22 January 2019|archive-date=23 January 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190123010255/https://www.statsf1.com/en/red-bull.aspx|url-status=live}} === TAG Heuer-badged Renault engines (2016–2018) === ==== 2016 season ==== {{see also|2016 Formula One World Championship}} For 2016, Red Bull Racing used Renault engines branded as [[TAG Heuer]]{{cite web |url=https://www.formula1.com/content/fom-website/en/latest/headlines/2015/12/red-bull-to-run-tag-heuer-badged-renault-engines-in-2016.html |title=Red Bull to run TAG Heuer-badged Renault engines in 2016 |work=formula1.com |date=4 December 2015 |access-date=10 March 2016 |archive-date=7 June 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160607164922/https://www.formula1.com/content/fom-website/en/latest/headlines/2015/12/red-bull-to-run-tag-heuer-badged-renault-engines-in-2016.html |url-status=live }} due to their public breakdown with Renault in 2015. Infiniti also departed as a main sponsor due to the Renault breakdown. The team announced on 17 March 2016, one day before the [[2016 Australian Grand Prix|Australian Grand Prix]] weekend, that they had formed a new technology partnership with [[Aston Martin]], for the new season.{{cite web|last1=Barretto|first1=Lawrence|last2=Rencken|first2=Dieter|title=Aston Martin makes return to Formula 1 with Red Bull tie-up|url=https://www.autosport.com/f1/news/123288/aston-martin-back-in-f1-with-red-bull|website=autosport.com|access-date=18 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160318105912/http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/123288/aston-martin-back-in-f1-with-red-bull|archive-date=18 March 2016|date=17 March 2016|url-status=live}} At the {{F1 GP|2016|Chinese}}, Red Bull recorded their first podium of the season with [[Daniil Kvyat]] finishing third behind [[Sebastian Vettel]] and [[Nico Rosberg]]. Daniil Kvyat and Max Verstappen traded places ahead of the {{F1 GP|2016|Spanish}}, with Verstappen promoted to Red Bull Racing and Kvyat returning to [[Scuderia Toro Rosso]].{{cite news|url=http://www.redbullracing.com/article/new-line-spain|title=New line-up for Spain|work=redbullracing.com|publisher=Red Bull Racing|date=5 May 2016|access-date=5 May 2016|archive-date=8 May 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160508080016/http://www.redbullracing.com/article/new-line-spain|url-status=live}} Verstappen eventually won the Spanish Grand Prix, becoming the youngest ever Grand Prix winner. [[File:Red Bull duo 2016 Malaysia Race.jpg|thumb|left|Together [[Daniel Ricciardo]] and [[Max Verstappen]] won two races during the 2016 season with the [[Red Bull RB12]].]] 2016 in general was a much stronger season for Red Bull Racing than 2015, especially after Max Verstappen replaced [[Daniil Kvyat]]. This may be because [[Daniel Ricciardo]] was pushed much more by Verstappen than he was by Kvyat, Ricciardo stating he has learned from Verstappen's driving techniques to improve as a driver.{{cite web |url=http://en.f1i.com/news/73054-ricciardo-learning-verstappens-driving-techniques.html |title=Ricciardo learning from Verstappen's driving techniques |work=en.f1i.com |date=26 September 2016 |access-date=4 October 2016 |archive-date=5 October 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161005131042/http://en.f1i.com/news/73054-ricciardo-learning-verstappens-driving-techniques.html |url-status=live }} Red Bull would go on to collect podium finishes with Max Verstappen in [[2016 Austrian Grand Prix|Austria]] and [[2016 British Grand Prix|Silverstone]], with Daniel Ricciardo in [[2016 Monaco Grand Prix|Monaco]], [[2016 Hungarian Grand Prix|Budapest]] and in [[2016 Singapore Grand Prix|Singapore]], with both Verstappen and Ricciardo being on the podium in [[2016 German Grand Prix|Germany]] and [[2016 Malaysian Grand Prix|Malaysia]]. Daniel Ricciardo collected his 4th career victory in [[2016 Malaysian Grand Prix|Malaysia]] after Lewis Hamilton's engine failure. Verstappen had challenged for the victory but was compromised due to an incident at the start between Vettel and Rosberg leading to Verstappen referring to Vettel as 'crazy'.{{cite web |url=http://www.motorsport.com/f1/news/verstappen-hits-out-at-ridiculous-vettel-move-832443/ |title=Verstappen hits out at "ridiculous" Vettel move |work=www.motorsport.com |date=2 October 2016 |access-date=4 October 2016 |archive-date=5 October 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161005094638/http://www.motorsport.com/f1/news/verstappen-hits-out-at-ridiculous-vettel-move-832443/ |url-status=live }} This incident was the latest flare-up between Vettel and Verstappen after the two disagreed over a first corner collision at the [[2016 Belgian Grand Prix|Belgian Grand Prix]] which resulted in Max failing to score at a race where he started on the front row, outqualifying his teammate for only the 2nd time, in which a large number of Dutch fans had traveled to see him race.{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/f1/news/12433/10556052/max-verstappen-hits-out-at-kimi-raikkonen-and-sebastian-vettel-after-belgian-gp |title=Max Verstappen hits out at Kimi Raikkonen and Sebastian Vettel after Belgian GP |work=www.skysports.com/f1 |date=5 September 2016 |access-date=4 October 2016 |archive-date=5 October 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161005132117/http://www.skysports.com/f1/news/12433/10556052/max-verstappen-hits-out-at-kimi-raikkonen-and-sebastian-vettel-after-belgian-gp |url-status=live }} Towards the end of the [[2016 Brazilian Grand Prix|Brazilian Grand Prix]] Verstappen dropped to 14th after changing back to wet tyres. He then gained an incredible 11 places in the closing 16 laps finishing on the podium in third. Red Bull Racing finished 2nd in the Constructors' Championship that year, with Daniel Ricciardo taking 3rd in the Drivers' Championship.{{cite web|url=http://www.redbullracing.com/article/highlights|title=Racing Record – Red Bull Racing Formula One Team|work=redbullracing.com|access-date=27 January 2017|archive-date=18 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170218150859/http://www.redbullracing.com/article/highlights|url-status=live}} ==== 2017 season ==== {{see also|2017 Formula One World Championship}} [[File:Max Verstappen (36132602681).jpg|thumb|right|Max Verstappen during the [[2017 Australian Grand Prix]]]] [[File:Red Bull Racing celebration, Malaysia GP 2017.jpg|thumb|right|Red Bull Racing celebrates a double podium finish in the [[2017 Malaysian Grand Prix]]]] In 2017, Red Bull Racing retained their 2016 driver line-up and continued using TAG Heuer-branded Renault engines. In the first race in [[2017 Australian Grand Prix|Australia]], Ricciardo retired on lap 25, in a weekend plagued with problems for him, while Verstappen finished 5th. Verstappen suffered various reliability issues with the car, suffering three retirements due to the engine and one due to an electric problem at the {{F1 GP|2017|Canadian}}. He was also involved in three first-lap collisions that ended in retirement. The team won three races in {{F1|2017}}; Ricciardo won the {{F1 GP|2017|Azerbaijan}} after starting tenth, while Verstappen won the {{F1 GP|2017|Malaysian}} and the {{F1 GP|2017|Mexican}}. Moreover, Verstappen and Ricciardo finished second and third at the {{F1 GP|2017|Japanese}}. In the Drivers' Championship, Ricciardo finished fifth with 200 points and Verstappen sixth with 168 points. The team finished third in the Constructors' Championship with 368 points. ==== 2018 season ==== {{see also|2018 Formula One World Championship}} [[File:Max Verstappen, Red Bull Racing F1 Team (43693639382).jpg|thumb|Max Verstappen at the [[2018 British Grand Prix]] at the [[Silverstone Circuit]]]] Ricciardo and Verstappen were both retained by the team for the 2018 season. On 25 September 2017, it was announced that [[Aston Martin]] would become Red Bull Racing's title sponsor from 2018.{{cite web|url=http://www.redbullracing.com/article/driving-future-innovation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170925102338/http://www.redbullracing.com/article/driving-future-innovation |title=Driving Future Innovation |publisher=Red Bull Racing |date=25 September 2017 |archive-date=25 September 2017 |access-date=1 October 2017}} The team suffered a double retirement at the {{F1 GP|2018|Bahrain}}; Ricciardo retired on lap 2 with an electrical issue, whilst Verstappen retired two laps later. Ricciardo then took the team's first win of the season at the following race, the {{F1 GP|2018|Chinese}}, having started sixth on the grid. During the {{F1 GP|2018|Azerbaijan}}, both drivers crashed into each other at Turn 1. The team achieved a podium with Verstappen, during the {{F1 GP|2018|Spanish}} securing the 3rd place, while Ricciardo achieved 5th place. At the {{F1 GP|2018|Monaco}} Red Bull had a dominant car due to its highly efficient high down-force setup. Ricciardo scored a pole position, and despite running into an engine issue costing him power, he eventually won the race. This incident re-ignited the bad relationship with its engine manufacturer, Renault. Meanwhile, Verstappen crashed during free practice 3 and started from 20th on the grid, finishing the race in 9th place. This race also put an end to a streak of incidents for Verstappen. Monaco was also the last race that saw Daniel Ricciardo on the podium with Red Bull, with him parting ways with the team and joining rival team Renault at the end of the season. The European season saw consistent podiums and a good form, with Verstappen winning Red Bull's home race at the Red Bull Ring during the {{F1 GP|2018|Austrian}}. The second half of the season saw great form from Verstappen and good development of the car, as Verstappen scored 6 out of 8 possible podiums, and was the driver which scored the most points following the 2018 World Champion Lewis Hamilton. Ricciardo had a spree of mechanical issues and retirements during the second half of the season, with him getting 7 retirements in total and no podiums after the first six races coming to the end of the season. Verstappen won the {{F1 GP|2018|Mexican}} from second after pole position was grabbed by his teammate, making it Red Bull's first front-row lock-out in the turbo-hybrid era. Verstappen was also finding himself in a back-to-back win at the [[Brazilian Grand Prix]] but clashed with rival Esteban Ocon as the latter tried to unlap himself, costing him the victory. Following the race the drivers conflicted, resulting in 2 days of public service for Verstappen, which he completed on 9 February 2019.{{Cite web|url=https://www.autosport.com/f1/news/141410/verstappen-completes-public-service-penalty|title=Max Verstappen completes Brazilian GP public service penalty|last=Horton|first=Phillip|website=Autosport.com|language=en|access-date=13 February 2019|archive-date=14 February 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190214002752/https://www.autosport.com/f1/news/141410/verstappen-completes-public-service-penalty|url-status=live}} Ricciardo's multiple retirements would end up costing both himself and Red Bull key points in the Drivers' and Constructors' Championships. Verstappen would finish the 2018 season in 4th place, just 3 points behind [[Kimi Räikkönen]] while Daniel Ricciardo would finish the season in 6th place, behind [[Valtteri Bottas]]. Red Bull would finish the season in 3rd place behind Mercedes and Ferrari. By the {{F1 GP|2018|French}}, Red Bull, encouraged by the progress of Honda in the sister team Scuderia Toro Rosso, decided that in 2019 it would officially end its relationship with Renault for the Honda power. === Works Honda engines (2019–2021) === ==== 2019 season ==== {{see also|2019 Formula One World Championship}} [[File:Max Verstappen 2019 Italian Grand Prix.jpg|thumb|right|Max Verstappen at the [[2019 Italian Grand Prix]]]] Preceding the 2018 {{F1 GP|2018|French}}, Red Bull Racing confirmed they are to utilise full-works [[Honda in Formula One|Honda]] power units from 2019 to 2020, signing a two-year deal and thus ending their twelve-year partnership with [[Renault F1|Renault]].{{cite web|url=https://redbullracing.redbull.com/article/honda-power-2019|title=Honda Power From 2019|first=Red Bull Racing Formula One|last=Team|website=redbull.com|access-date=11 August 2018|archive-date=14 August 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180814154559/http://redbullracing.redbull.com/article/honda-power-2019|url-status=live}} On 3 August 2018, it was announced that Ricciardo would be leaving the team at the end of the season to join [[Renault in Formula One|Renault]], signing a two-year contract with them.{{cite web|url=https://www.formula1.com/en/latest/headlines/2018/8/ricciardo-joins-hulkenberg-at-renault-in-2019.html|title=Ricciardo to join Hulkenberg at Renault for 2019|website=formula1.com|access-date=11 August 2018|archive-date=15 August 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180815223123/https://www.formula1.com/en/latest/headlines/2018/8/ricciardo-joins-hulkenberg-at-renault-in-2019.html|url-status=live}} [[Pierre Gasly]] was promoted from Toro Rosso to replace him.{{cite web |url=https://redbullracing.redbull.com/article/going-full-gas-2019 |title=Going full Gas in 2019 |publisher=Red Bull Racing |date=20 August 2018 |access-date=20 August 2018 |archive-date=20 August 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180820234919/https://redbullracing.redbull.com/article/going-full-gas-2019 |url-status=live }} On 12 August 2019, it was announced that [[Alex Albon]] would move to Red Bull Racing for the rest of the season, replacing Gasly, who returned to Toro Rosso.{{cite web |url=https://redbullracing.redbull.com/article/alex-joins-team |title=Alex joins the team |publisher=Red Bull Racing |date=12 August 2019 |access-date=12 August 2019 |archive-date=12 August 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190812104837/https://redbullracing.redbull.com/article/alex-joins-team |url-status=live }} ==== 2020 season ==== {{See also|2020 Formula One World Championship}} [[File:Alexander Albon 2020 Tuscan Grand Prix - race day.jpg|thumb|Albon racing at the [[2020 Tuscan Grand Prix]]]] The team retained Max Verstappen and Alex Albon as their line-up for the 2020 season. [[Alex Albon]] scored his first-ever Formula One podium at the {{F1GP|2020|Tuscan}}. ==== 2021 season ==== {{See also|2021 Formula One World Championship}} [[File:FIA F1 Austria 2021 Nr. 11 Perez.jpg|thumb|Pérez at the [[2021 Austrian Grand Prix]]]] In October 2020, engine manufacturer Honda announced it would end its full-works participation in Formula One at the end of the 2021 season.{{Cite web|title=Could Red Bull really take on Honda's engines in 2022?|url=https://www.motorsport.com/f1/news/red-bull-honda-engines-2022/4888860/|access-date=18 December 2020|website=www.motorsport.com|language=en|archive-date=30 January 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220130102743/https://www.motorsport.com/f1/news/red-bull-honda-engines-2022/4888860/|url-status=live}} Verstappen was contracted to continue racing for the team with experienced Mexican [[Sergio Pérez]] becoming his teammate as Albon took the reserve driver role.{{Cite web|title=Perez to partner Verstappen at Red Bull in 2021, as Albon becomes reserve driver|url=https://www.formula1.com/en/latest/article.breaking-perez-to-partner-verstappen-at-red-bull-in-2021-as-albon-becomes.21qHfmHAyfzAjVHT3PfVBd.html|access-date=19 December 2020|website=formula1.com|language=en|archive-date=18 December 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201218140613/https://www.formula1.com/en/latest/article.breaking-perez-to-partner-verstappen-at-red-bull-in-2021-as-albon-becomes.21qHfmHAyfzAjVHT3PfVBd.html|url-status=live}} Verstappen took pole position at the season-opening [[2021 Bahrain Grand Prix|Bahrain Grand Prix]]. Verstappen was later out-qualified by [[Sergio Pérez]] at the [[2021 Emilia Romagna Grand Prix]], but went on to win the race and be just one point behind Lewis Hamilton in the Drivers' Championship standings. At the [[2021 Monaco Grand Prix|Monaco Grand Prix]], Red Bull Racing took the lead of the Constructors' Championship for the first time since the [[2013 Brazilian Grand Prix]] as a result of another Verstappen win and a poor result for Mercedes. Verstappen also took the lead in the championship for the first time in his career after the race. In the [[2021 Azerbaijan Grand Prix|Azerbaijan Grand Prix]] Verstappen led the majority of the race and looked set to win before a late-race tyre blowout. Pérez won the race. Verstappen then took pole and won the next three races while Pérez took one more podium in France to grow Red Bull's championship lead. At [[Silverstone Circuit|Silverstone]], Red Bull was beaten in Friday qualifying but Verstappen won the sprint on Saturday to claim a 4th consecutive pole position. During the race, Hamilton and Verstappen made contact at Copse corner, resulting in Verstappen crashing out of the race. In [[2021 Hungarian Grand Prix|Hungary]], both Red Bulls suffered severe damage in a first-lap accident triggered by Mercedes' [[Valtteri Bottas]]. Pérez was out of the race, Verstappen managed to salvage a 9th-place finish. In [[2021 Belgian Grand Prix|Spa]] Verstappen took pole and won a rain-shortened race in which half points were awarded. In [[2021 Italian Grand Prix|Italy]], Hamilton and Verstappen made contact yet again at the Rettifilo chicane which resulted in both drivers retiring from the race, and Verstappen receiving a 3-place grid penalty for the next race, as the stewards judged him at fault for the collision. At the [[2021 Abu Dhabi Grand Prix|Abu Dhabi Grand Prix]], Verstappen took pole position, his first since [[2021 United States Grand Prix|Austin]]. He secured his first world title and a first championship for the team since 2013 with a last lap overtake on Hamilton. On 10 October 2022, the FIA announced that Red Bull were one of two teams who had breached the 2021 Financial Regulations applicable during the season, with Red Bull committing what was described as "a Procedural Breach and a Minor Financial Overspend (less than 5% of the Cost Cap)".{{Cite web |title=FIA announces 2021 Cost Cap breaches by two F1 teams {{!}} Formula 1® |url=https://www.formula1.com/en/latest/article.fia-announces-2021-cost-cap-breaches-by-two-f1-teams.2N8xy1FHhoOlwsOO3Mx0A2.html |access-date=10 October 2022 |website=www.formula1.com |language=en |archive-date=10 October 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221010155942/https://www.formula1.com/en/latest/article.fia-announces-2021-cost-cap-breaches-by-two-f1-teams.2N8xy1FHhoOlwsOO3Mx0A2.html |url-status=live }} On 28 October 2022, the FIA announced that Red Bull had entered an Accepted Breach Agreement; in summary Red Bull were in breach of 13 points of non-compliance.{{Cite web |title=Red Bull enter Agreement with FIA over breach of 2021 Financial Regulations {{!}} Formula 1® |url=https://www.formula1.com/en/latest/article.red-bull-enter-agreement-with-fia-over-breach-of-2021-financial-regulations.2ccVAHxnUpChqHSIDGMXmg.html |access-date=28 October 2022 |website=www.formula1.com |language=en |archive-date=28 October 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221028144205/https://www.formula1.com/en/latest/article.red-bull-enter-agreement-with-fia-over-breach-of-2021-financial-regulations.2ccVAHxnUpChqHSIDGMXmg.html |url-status=live }} The agreement resulted in a $7m fine and a 10% reduction in permitted aerodynamic research. === RBPT-badged works Honda engines (2022–present) === ==== 2022 season ==== [[File:2022 official information was published on the approval of an application submitted jointly by [[Porsche]] and [[Red Bull GmbH]] in which Porsche acquired 50% of the shares in Red Bull Technology, the parent company of Red Bull Racing and its Formula One program. This application had to be filed with the antitrust authorities of up to 20 countries, including outside the [[European Union]]. The press release was due to go out for the [[2022 Austrian Grand Prix|Austrian GP]], however the [[Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile|FIA]] did not approve the regulations for the 2026 engines before 29 June as planned, delaying official confirmation of Porsche's entry into Formula One{{Cite web |title=Leak durch Kartellbehörde: Porsche übernimmt 50 Prozent von Red Bull! |url=https://www.motorsport-total.com/formel-1/news/leak-durch-kartellbehoerde-porsche-uebernimmt-50-prozent-von-red-bull-22072708 |access-date=27 July 2022 |website=Motorsport-Total.com |language=de |archive-date=27 July 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220727133617/https://www.motorsport-total.com/formel-1/news/leak-durch-kartellbehoerde-porsche-uebernimmt-50-prozent-von-red-bull-22072708 |url-status=live }} However, after months of speculation, Porsche AG confirmed in September that talks with Red Bull GmbH would not continue. The intention was to reach an engine and team partnership, based on equal footing but the negotiations never came to fruition.{{Cite web |title=Partnership between Porsche AG and Red Bull GmbH will
