2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220123070414/https://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/108666-fastest-formula-one-pit-stop|url-status=live}} == Corporate information == === Image and marketing === [[File:Red Bull helmet stand.jpg|thumb|150px|A distinctive RBR helmet-shaped stand.]] Red Bull has been very vocal about wanting to make Formula One 'fun' again. One way in which they went about doing that was by employing Mark Gallagher, who was head of marketing for nine years at [[Jordan Grand Prix|Jordan]], itself an exciting brand in the late 1990s.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2005/feb/28/formulaone.motorracing35 |title=Got wings? |newspaper=The Guardian |date=28 February 2005 |access-date=28 April 2009 |archive-date=10 August 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140810190637/http://www.theguardian.com/sport/2005/feb/28/formulaone.motorracing35 |url-status=live }} Red Bull also started ''[[The Red Bulletin]]'', a sports and adventure magazine that is released four times per race weekend and distributed to the paddock and members of the public from behind the main grandstand at each track.{{citation needed|reason=is released four times per race weekend|date=May 2016}} In the [[2006 Monaco Grand Prix]], they supported the movie ''[[Superman Returns]]'', which continues the line of marketing events begun by the ''[[Star Wars: Episode III – Revenge of the Sith]]'' promotion of 2005 (in the 2005 race, the pit crew dressed up as [[clone trooper]]s) and the ''[[Ocean's Twelve]]'' promotion of 2004, as well as ''[[Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines]]'' promotion of 2003 when the team ran under the [[Jaguar Racing]] banner. When Coulthard finished third in the 2006 race, he donned a [[Superman]] cape for his appearance on the podium. In the [[2019 British Grand Prix]], [[James Bond|007]] logos were used in the livery to replace the [[Aston Martin]] logos, to celebrate the 1007th Grand Prix. The cars also had Bond-themed number plates on the underside of their rear wings. Max Verstappen had the number plate from the [[Aston Martin DB5]] from ''[[Goldfinger (film)|Goldfinger]]'' (BMT 216A) while [[Pierre Gasly]]'s car featured the [[Aston Martin V8]] plate (B549 WUU) from ''[[The Living Daylights]]''.{{Cite web|url = https://www.007.com/007-and-aston-martin-red-bull-racing-team-up/|title = 007 and Aston Martin Red Bull Racing Team up|date = 11 July 2019|access-date = 12 February 2020|archive-date = 16 July 2019|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20190716181624/https://www.007.com/007-and-aston-martin-red-bull-racing-team-up/|url-status = live}} Both drivers wore special racing overalls with a print of a single-breasted dinner suit.{{Cite web | url=https://redbullracing.redbull.com/article/shaken-not-stirred-0 | title=Shaken, not Stirred | access-date=12 February 2020 | archive-date=29 September 2019 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190929070117/https://redbullracing.redbull.com/article/shaken-not-stirred-0 | url-status=live }} The 007 logo was first used during their race as Jaguar in the [[2002 Formula One World Championship|2002 season]] to promote ''[[Die Another Day]]''. === Finances === Red Bull Racing had revenue of $285.4 million and expenses of $284.4 million in 2011. The revenue came from prize money ($88.8 million), sponsors ($59.7 million), and the remainder from Red Bull. Expenses included $112.8 million in research and development and $82.7 million in salaries for 605 employees.{{cite journal|last=Sylt|first=Christian|author2=Morrison, |website=Companies House}} Red Bull Technology was regarded as a loop-hole to allow Red Bull to run two teams with the same car from 2007, which had been prohibited in Formula One since the 1980s. Complaints were issued to the FIA from rival teams, but they were discarded by the sport's governing body.{{cite news|first=Jonathan|last=Noble|title=Stewards reject Spyker protest|url=http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/57832|work=Autosport|publisher=Haymarket Media|date=6 April 2007|access-date=9 October 2013|archive-date=11 February 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120211144858/http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/57832|url-status=live}} Neither Red Bull Racing nor Scuderia Toro Rosso denied they ran fundamentally the same chassis, but claimed the separate development programs, different engines and in their opinion that the chassis was designed by neither team made it legal.{{cite news|title=F1 Teams threaten legal action against each other |url=http://www.bitsofnews.com/content/view/4933/42/ |publisher=bitsofnews.com |date=7 February 2007 |access-date=9 October 2013 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140311062710/http://www.bitsofnews.com/content/view/4933/42/ |archive-date=11 March 2014 }} The regulations were changed in 2010 to forbid the use of identical cars between teams, and Toro Rosso no longer had its cars produced by Red Bull Technology. Since then the team designed and built their cars, having built the necessary infrastructure in-house.{{cite web|title=Toro Rosso F1 car unveiled|url=http://www.autocar.co.uk/car-news/motorsport/toro-rosso-f1-car-unveiled|work=Autocar|publisher=Haymarket Media|access-date=9 October 2013|archive-date=10 June 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150610200359/http://www.autocar.co.uk/car-news/motorsport/toro-rosso-f1-car-unveiled|url-status=live}} Red Bull Technology also supplied [[Scuderia Toro Rosso]], later Scuderia AlphaTauri as their gearbox partner from 2006 to present and KERS supplier from 2011 to 2013. They also served [[Team Lotus (2010–11)|Team Lotus]], later [[Caterham F1]] as gearbox supplier from 2011 to 2014 and KERS supplier from 2012 to 2013. Red Bull Technology uses ''[[rFactor Pro]]'' driving simulation software.{{cite web|title=Driving Red Bull's rFactor Pro Simulator|url=http://www.virtualr.net/driving-red-bulls-rfactor-pro-simulator|website=VirtualR|date=3 September 2009|access-date=31 August 2015|archive-date=8 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208151708/http://www.virtualr.net/driving-red-bulls-rfactor-pro-simulator|url-status=live}}{{cite web|title=Inside Red Bull's rFactor Pro Simulator – Video|url=http://www.virtualr.net/inside-red-bulls-rfactor-pro-simulator-video|website=VirtualR|date=31 May 2010|access-date=31 August 2015|archive-date=31 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150531220920/http://www.virtualr.net/inside-red-bulls-rfactor-pro-simulator-video|url-status=live}}{{cite web|title=The Red Bull Simulator|url=http://www.f1simulatormaniac.com/formula-1-2015/red-bull-simulator-f1-racing/|website=F1 Simulator Maniac|access-date=31 August 2015|archive-date=24 September 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924005254/http://www.f1simulatormaniac.com/formula-1-2015/red-bull-simulator-f1-racing/|url-status=live}} === Red Bull Advanced Technologies === Red Bull Advanced Technologies (RBAT) is owned by Red Bull GmbH and serves as the commercial technology and engineering services arm of Red Bull Racing. The company is based in the United Kingdom, in a dedicated facility, adjacent to the Red Bull Racing Formula One facilities. Red Bull Advanced Technologies in collaboration with [[Aston Martin]] have developed the [[Aston Martin Valkyrie]] sports car.{{cite web |url=http://www.express.co.uk/life-style/cars/775692/Aston-Martin-Valkyrie-Red-Bull-AM-RB-001-hypercar-new-name |title=Aston Martin Valkyrie, Red Bull Racing hypercar's new name unveiled |last=John Smith |first=Luke |publisher=Northern and Shell Media |date=6 March 2017 |website=Express |access-date=13 June 2017 |archive-date=23 April 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170423184730/http://www.express.co.uk/life-style/cars/775692/Aston-Martin-Valkyrie-Red-Bull-AM-RB-001-hypercar-new-name |url-status=live }} Red Bull Advanced Technologies in a collaborative effort with [[Dallara]] and [[IndyCar]], developed the 'aeroscreen' safety device for usage in the [[2020 IndyCar Series]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.indycar.com/News/2019/05/05-24-Aeroscreen-Red-Bull-announcement|title=INDYCAR announces plan for cockpit protection innovation|website=IndyCar.com|access-date=13 October 2019|archive-date=15 September 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200915090316/https://www.indycar.com/News/2019/05/05-24-Aeroscreen-Red-Bull-announcement|url-status=live}} Red Bull Advanced Technologies announced in June 2022 that they were developing a hypercar completely in house, named the RB17, in line with their Formula One car naming scheme. The car would be designed by [[Adrian Newey]], Chief Technical Officer at Red Bull Racing. Only 50 units are to be made, with production scheduled to begin in 2025.{{Cite web |date=2022-06-28 |title=Red Bull Advanced Technologies Announces The RB17 |url=https://www.redbulladvancedtechnologies.com/red-bull-advanced-technologies-announces-the-rb17/ |access-date=2023-03-10 |website=Red Bull Advanced Technologies |language=en-GB |archive-date=17 October 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221017081253/https://www.redbulladvancedtechnologies.com/red-bull-advanced-technologies-announces-the-rb17/ |url-status=live }} {{Clear}} == Scuderia AlphaTauri == {{Main|Scuderia Toro Rosso|Scuderia AlphaTauri}} In the autumn of 2005, Red Bull announced that they had purchased the cash-strapped [[Minardi]] Formula One team, and it would be known as [[Scuderia Toro Rosso]] (Italian for ''Team Red Bull'') from 2006 onwards. Scuderia Toro Rosso (STR) operates as a separate team, but the two share certain technical resources. In 2006 STR used a chassis based on the 2005 Red Bull Racing [[Red Bull RB1]] chassis, originally designed by Jaguar Racing, and Minardi's contracted supply of rev-limited [[V10 engine|V10]] [[Cosworth]] engines. It was widely speculated that the 2007 chassis for both teams would be essentially the same [[Adrian Newey]] design, although Red Bull was careful to announce that the "STR2 will be built by Red Bull Technology, and Toro Rosso will fully own the intellectual rights of the car".{{cite news|url=http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/56126|first=Jonathan|last=Noble|title=Berger confident STR2 will get green light|work=autosport.com|date=3 January 2007|publisher=[[Haymarket Group|Haymarket Publications]]|access-date=28 April 2009|archive-date=22 February 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080222100342/http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/56126|url-status=live}} Formula One teams are not allowed to use another team's chassis. STR has been used as a 'B' team for Red Bull Racing, allowing the company to work with more drivers. As of the 2010 season this arrangement was outlawed, and the STR5 is the first Toro Rosso car designed and built in-house.{{cite news|url=http://www.gpupdate.net/en/f1-news/227186/first-own-design-for-toro-rosso/|title=First own-design for Toro Rosso|work=gpupdate.net|date=1 February 2010|publisher=GPUpdate|access-date=17 March 2010|archive-date=25 November 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101125212048/http://www.gpupdate.net/en/f1-news/227186/first-own-design-for-toro-rosso/|url-status=live}} In 2006, Red Bull Racing driver [[Vitantonio Liuzzi]] was given a full-time seat with Scuderia Toro Rosso alongside another Red Bull sponsored driver, [[Scott Speed]]. Liuzzi retained his seat in STR for the 2007 season. [[Sebastian Vettel]] replaced Speed in the middle of the 2007 season, and [[Sébastien Bourdais]] replaced Liuzzi at STR for the {{F1|2008}} season. Against expectation, Toro Rosso performed well during the 2008 season and Sebastian Vettel won the [[2008 Italian Grand Prix]]. This meant that Toro Rosso took their first win before Red Bull Racing, and helped to secure Vettel a drive with Red Bull Racing for 2009 when he also took that team's first win. For {{F1|2020}}, the team was rebranded as Scuderia AlphaTauri, after [[AlphaTauri (Fashion Brand)|AlphaTauri]], Red Bull's fashion brand. Scuderia AlphaTauri achieved their maiden Grand Prix win under the new name at the [[2020 Italian Grand Prix]]. The race marked [[Pierre Gasly]]'s first career race victory and the first for a French driver since [[Olivier Panis]] won the [[1996 Monaco Grand Prix]] 24 years prior. == Fictional racing car == {{Main| Red Bull X2010}} The Red Bull X2010, originally named Red Bull X1, is a fictional car featured in the video games ''[[Gran Turismo 5]]'', ''[[Gran Turismo 6]]'' and ''[[Gran Turismo Sport]]'' (which has both the Red Bull X2010 Junior and the regular one). The [[prototype]] vehicle was made to answer [[Kazunori Yamauchi]]'s question: "If you built the fastest racing car on land, one that throws aside all rules and regulations, what would that car look like, how would it perform, and how would it feel to drive?" The vehicle was designed by [[Adrian Newey]] in conjunction with Yamauchi. It features enclosed wheels and a "fan element" to increase low and medium-speed downforce, much like a [[Chaparral 2J]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gtplanet.net/gran-turismo-5s-red-bull-x1-prototype-revealed-wspecs|title=Gran Turismo 5's Red Bull X1 Prototype Revealed (w/Specs!)|date=18 October 2010|access-date=18 November 2014|work=GTPlanet|publisher=GTPlanet Networks|archive-date=1 December 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141201210353/http://www.gtplanet.net/gran-turismo-5s-red-bull-x1-prototype-revealed-wspecs/|url-status=live}} == Racing record == {{main|Red Bull Racing Grand Prix results}} As a constructor, Red Bull Racing have achieved the following statistics: * Constructors' Championships winning percentage: {{Percentage|5|18|1}} * Drivers' Championships winning percentage: {{Percentage|6|18|1}} * Winning percentage: {{Percentage|{{f1cstat|RBR|wins}}|{{f1cstat|RBR|entries}}|1}} ('''Bold''' indicates championships won.) {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; font-size:85%" |- !
